quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Langford House
listingDescription: View the remains of a house built by J.O. Langford in 1909-1910 on a hill overlooking the hot springs.

images.altText: A stone house with two rooms sits on a limestone hill.
images.title: Langford House
images.caption: Two room addition to the original adobe structure

bodyText:
In May of 1909, J.O. Langford, his wife, Bessie, and their 18-month old daughter, Lovie, moved to land he had recently acquired around the hot springs. Their first home was an abandoned dug-out, over whose rock walls they stretched a tent. In November 1909 Langford completed a one-room adobe cabin, 12x14 feet and 9 feet high, on a bench of land 150 feet above the river and overlooking the hot springs. During their second year of occupation, Langford enlarged his house by building two more rooms of stone. Unfortunately, this structure has since entirely disintegrated. The only elements that can be seen today are the remains of the poured concrete floor of the stone addition.
The picture shown was the two-room stone addition to the original adobe structure, which can barely be seen through the doorway. The date of the photo is unknown, but the fact that the structure is deteriorated suggests that it was photographed after 1942, when the land was sold for eventual donation to the national park.
audioDescription: The Langford House is situated on a limestone hill, about 150 feet above the Rio Grande. From this location, one has a view of the river and the surrounding terrain, both in the United States, and across the river into Mexico. The vegetation includes low desert cactus, ocotillo, creosotebush, and mesquite, as well as low trees, cane, and tamarisk that are associated with water. The only visible remains of the Langford house are the concrete floor that was poured when the addition was built.

quickFacts.value: 0.5 mile walk from the parking lot
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Livingston House
listingDescription: View a beautiful rock house to the west of the hot springs built by Alpine resident Charles Livingston.

images.altText: A rock house with lots of windows sits on a limestone hill
images.title: Livingston House at Hot Springs
images.caption: Livingston House

bodyText: Charles Livingston, an undertaker from Alpine, bought land just west of the Hot Springs post office from J.O. Langford in the late 1920s or early 1930s. Soon after, he built a beautiful rock house on a hill overlooking Tornillo Creek. The house is constructed of native stone and local materials. It later served as a temporary residence during the early days of the national park.
audioDescription: A house composed of irregularly-shaped rocks of different colors rests on a small hill. It has numerous large windows, a door facing the hot springs, and a chimney. The wooden beams used as supports and decoration around the windows and doors are still in place. It has a level concrete floor and stone steps leading up the hill to a small stone wall surrounding the house. The hillside behind the house is sparsely vegetated with creosotebush, prickly pear cactus, and ocotillo. There is no surrounding shade, and the lack of a roof gives the structure a feeling of intensely hot desolation.

quickFacts.value: On a hill overlooking the parking lot
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lone Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription: A moderate, 3-mile trail in the desert.

images.altText: A sign and path mark the beginning of the loop trail.
images.title: Lone Mountain Trailhead
images.caption: Lone Mountain Trailhead

bodyText:
Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 2.7 miles (4.8 km) 
Elevation change: 200 feet (61 m)
Average hiking time: 1-2 hours


The Lone Mountain trail leaves from here. This is a moderately challenging 2.7-mile loop with approximately 200 feet of elevation gain. It features wide open views into the desert, diverse desert plants, and a close look at a volcanic mountain. 

Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

There is no shade along this desert trail.
 

Accessibility

While this trail is generally flat, there are a few sections with gradual climbs and descents. Most of the trail is rocky or covered with loose pebbles. Please be aware of your footing.

Hike Smart

Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed, or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.

title: Lost Mine Trail
listingDescription: The Lost Mine Trail climbs to the side of Lost Mine Peak, offering spectacular views of Juniper Canyon and the Northeast Rim of the Chisos.

images.altText: A mountainside with desert plants and trees with a tall rocky peak in the background
images.title: Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: Hike along the base of Casa Grande Peak.

bodyText:
Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 4.8 miles (7.7 km) 
Elevation Change: 1100 feet (335 m)
Average hiking time: 3 hours

Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

This trail serves as an outstanding introduction to the flora and fauna of the Chisos Mountains. With limited time, hike in about one mile and stop at the saddle for stunning views of Casa Grande Peak and Juniper Canyon. The remainder of the trail climbs steeply in and out of juniper, oak, and pine forest. The trail abruptly levels out at a ridge with superb views of Pine Canyon and the Sierra del Carmen in Mexico.

Accessibility

Parking is limited. The small parking lot holds 15 vehicles and regularly fills between 8 am and 9 am from November through April (peak season).
A wheelchair-accessible sidewalk leads to an information panel. Behind the panel, the dirt and rock hiking trail ascends along a drainage with trees and desert plants. There are numerous log steps that assist with the challenging 1,100 feet of elevation change.

Hike Smart

Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.
audioDescription: This trailhead sign is accessed from a narrow, parking lot that is large enough to accommodate about fifteen cars. A wheelchair accessible sidewalk leads to an information panel that is mounted on metal legs. Behind the panel, the hiking trail ascends along a drainage with trees and desert plants. The panel shows a photo of Juniper Canyon, a large canyon covered in green vegetation and surrounded by a rocky rim. The panel also shows a topographic map of the Lost Mine Trail, the Chisos Basin Road, and Juniper Canyon. Photo courtesy of Tim McKenna Text from sign: "The Lost Mine Trail climbs to the side of Lost Mine Peak, offering spectacular views of Juniper Canyon and the Northeast Rim of the Chisos. These vistas begin around 1 mile up and continue to the top of the trail. Lost Mine Peak was named for the legend of the lost mine of the Chisos. As the story goes, Spanish explorers discovered ore here on their quest for silver and gold. They enslaved the native Chizo tribe and forced them to work the mine, blindfolding them to keep the location of the mine secret. According to the legend, the Chizo revolted, killing every last Spanish captor and sealing the entrance of the mine. Some say, by standing on the doorway of the church of San Vicente, Mexico, the first light on Easter morning will shine on the mine’s hidden location. The Lost Mine of the Chisos remains legend, as no ore bearing rocks have been reported from these hills. Whether this is just a story passed around campfires, or based on truth, the peak and all it includes is forever protected and preserved."

quickFacts.value: 5.5 miles up Chisos Basin Road
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #1
listingDescription: This is the first stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. This is a chance to closely examine the Mexican pinyon pine, a tree only found in Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.

images.altText: Several green pine cones are growing along the end of a tree branch.
images.title: Pinyon Pine
images.caption: Green pine cones

bodyText: Mexican pinyon pine (Pinus cembroides) is one of the most common evergreens in the Chisos Mountains. The seeds, or nuts, were an important food source for indigenous peoples as they are high in calories. The nuts also provide food for many animals, from squirrels to foxes to black bears.The nuts of a closer relative, Pinus edulis, are sold in grocery stores and are used to make pesto, hummus, and as salad toppers. This tree's range in the United States is confined to Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.
audioDescription: The pinon pine is located alongside a paved section of hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #10
listingDescription: This is the tenth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. This low saddle affords a great view to the east into Juniper Canyon and the desert beyond.

images.altText: The views from a high saddle encompass a long canyon and the desert in the distance.
images.title: View into Juniper Canyon
images.caption: View into Juniper Canyon

bodyText: This low saddle between peaks is a great turn-around point for a shorter hike (2 miles round-trip.) The view to the east encompasses Juniper Canyon, the Northeast Rim of the Chisos, and the lower desert beyond. An early morning arrival affords an opportunity to watch the rising sun highlight Casa Grande and the rocky cliffs of the Northeast Rim.
audioDescription: From this saddle, the view drops into Juniper Canyon. The change in vegetation with the drop in elevation is obvious. From trees, shrubs, and grasses to low bushes, cacti, and cholla, the warmer temperatures in the low desert are quite evident.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #11
listingDescription: This is the third stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. At this location one can view an ocotillo and learn about several adaptations they have evolved to survive in the desert.

images.altText: Long, tubular red flowers grow in a cluster at the end of an ocotillo stalk.
images.title: Ocotillo Flower
images.caption: Ocotillo flowers

bodyText: This branching plant is often mistaken for a cactus, but it is really in a family all its own (Fouquieriaceae). Ocotillo means "little pine" in Spanish. Ocotillo conserves water by shedding its leaves during dry periods. It grows new leaves after rainfall, sometimes within 48 hours of heavy rain, and retains them as long as it has adequate moisture. In the spring, a cluster of red flowers grows at the tip of each branch. Watch for hummingbirds feeding on those flowers.
audioDescription: The ocotillo is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #12
listingDescription: This is the twelfth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here is an opportunity to examine lechuguilla up close.

images.altText: Several plants with short, thick leaves with a sharp point on the end grow along a hillside.
images.title: Lechuguilla
images.caption: Cluster of lechuguilla plants

bodyText: Lechuguilla is an indicator plant of the Chihuahuan Desert, meaning it only grows in this region. After storing nutrients for 5-10 years, it sends up a bloom stalk that may be 15 feet tall. Like the agave, the entire plant dies after blooming. It reproduces primarily by sending out rhizome-like offshoots. The plant's tough fibers are used in making twine and rope, sacks, mats, cushions, and brushes. Take care around this plant, as the sharp spine on the end of the leaf can create a painful wound if one is unfortunate enough to make contact with it.
audioDescription: These lechuguilla plants are located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #13
listingDescription: This is the fourth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. Here you can learn more about the sotol, a common plant found in middle elevations in the park.

images.altText: A plant with long, thin leaves that have serrated edges grows on a desert slope.
images.title: Sotol
images.caption: Sotol

bodyText: Sotol is a evergreen rosette plant, with long spine-clad leaves that attach around a shortened, central stem. Although sotol is sometimes called a "cactus" or an "agave," it is neither. The sotol blooms from April to July, producing a flower stalk from 5-20 feet tall. Mexicans distill a fiery alcoholic drink, also known as sotol, from its juice. Indigenous peoples wove the leaves into useful items such as baskets and mats.
audioDescription: The sotol is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #14
listingDescription: This is the fourteenth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we discuss the claret cup cactus..

images.altText: A small, ribbed cactus is growing in the shadow of a larger agave.
images.title: Strawberry Pitaya and Agave
images.caption: Strawberry Pitaya beneath Agave

bodyText: Look closely - hiding just to the right of, and almost beneath, the large agave is a claret cup cactus. Its name comes from the bright, waxy reddish-orange flowers seen each April and May. Hummingbirds are its primary pollinator. The vertical grooves in the stems of the claret cup allow them to expand like an accordian to store water. Like all cacti, the claret cup's leaves have been modfied into spines that provide some shade and protection from predators while reducing moisture loss.
audioDescription: The claret cup cactus is located alongside a dirt hiking trail, almost beneath a large agave. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #15
listingDescription: This is the fifteenth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. This affords a close look at a group of prickly pear cactus, which sport beautiful blooms in April and May.

images.altText: A prickly pear cactus sports a yellow bloom on the side of one pad.
images.title: Prickly Pear Bloom
images.caption: Prickly pear cactus bloom

bodyText: More species of cacti have been identified in Big Bend National Park than in any other national park. Prickly pear cactus are the most common type of cacti found here, but in the lower elevations one can find other varieties such as cholla, rainbow cactus, eagle claw cactus, barrel cactus, and tasajillo. Shallow surface roots collect all available water, which the cactus stores in thick, waxy-covered pads, or stems. The pads are a good source of moisture, fiber, and nutrients for animals that brave the spines. Rodents bite into the edges of the pads between the spines, while javalinas have tough mouths that allow them to eat the entire pad, spines and all. The juicy ripe purple fruits are also a good food source for many animals.
audioDescription: These prickly pear cacti are located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #16
listingDescription: This is the sixteenth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. Here one has a great view to the south of Casa Grande, Toll Mountain, and the East Rim.

images.altText: A view to the south encompasses two high peaks and a high, long series of cliffs.
images.title: Mountain Views
images.caption: The bulk of the Chisos Mountains

bodyText: Standing at this viewpoint, one has a great view of the bulk of the Chisos Mountains. From right to left are Casa Grande, Toll Mountain, and the Northeast Rim. Initially formed from volcanic activity, the Chisos Mountains have also been shaped by faulting and erosion. Researches continue to study these and other formations throughout the park to learn more about the geologic processes that formed this landscape.
audioDescription: At this point in the trail one is standing near the edge of a cliff, looking towards the south. The peaks of Casa Grande, Toll Mountain, and the cliffs of the East Rim. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #17
listingDescription: This is the seventeenth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we talk about birds of the Chisos Basin and their songs.

images.altText: A bird with a black head and back, red patch on top of the head, and white belly clings to a tree.
images.title: Acorn Woodpecker
images.caption: What a cute clown face!

bodyText: During your walk thus far, how many different bird songs do you think you have heard? Resident birds that can be heard or seen year round incude Spotted Towhee, Canyon Towhee, Canyon Wren, Bewick's Wren, Black-crested Titmouse, Rufou-crowned Sparrow, and Acorn Woodpecker. The call of the Acorn Woodpecker is distinctive and can be heard at any elevation in the Chisos Mountains. Their most common call is a loud waka-waka-waka which is frequently used for greeting family members or disputing territory boundaries. Looking a bit like wide-eyed clowns, Acorn Woodpeckers store thousands of acorns each year by jamming them into specially made holes in trees. A family member is always on alert to guard their acorn hoard from thieves such as black bear.
audioDescription: This location has several large rocks and some shade which makes it a great place to take a break. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #18
listingDescription: This is the eighteenth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. This affords a close-up look at nolina, also known as bear grass.

images.altText: A plant with narrow, thin leaves and a flower stalk, all growing from the center of the plant.
images.title: Bear Grass
images.caption: Nolina or Bear Grass

bodyText: Nolina, also known as bear grass or basketgrass, closely resembles sotol, but it's leaf edges have a rough sandpapery feel instead of little teeth. Nolina sends up a short grassy bloom stalk every year. As with the sotol, Indigenous peoples also used the long slender leaves of nolina to make baskets, sandals, and mats.
audioDescription: The nolina is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #19
listingDescription: This is the nineteenth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we discuss oak trees and the large variety of species in the park.

images.altText: Several thin branches are adorned with oval shaped leaves about 2 inches in length.
images.title: Oak Leaves
images.caption: Oak leaves

bodyText: About 17 species of oaks are found in the Chisos Mountains. They can be difficult to identify due to their tendency to hybridize between species. Several notable species along this trail include Emory oak, gray oak, and Graves oak. A number of birds and mammals eat the acorns from these oaks including black bears, deer, javelina, squirrels, acorn woodpeckers, and Mexican jays.
audioDescription: This oak tree is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #2
listingDescription: This is the second stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we talk about the return of black bears to Big Bend and an information sign says what to do if you encounter a bear.

images.altText: A medium-size black bear stands on a rocky hillside, looking back at the camera.
images.title: Mexican Black Bear
images.caption: Mexican black bear

bodyText: In the early 1900s, black bears were common in the Chisos Mountains. By the time the national park was established in 1944, there were virtually no resident bears left. Shooting and trapping by ranchers, federal predator control agents, recreational hunters, and loss of habitat contributed to their decline. Individual bears occasionally wandered in and out of the park from Mexico, but only scattered sightings were reported from the 1940s through the 1980s. In the late 1980s visitors began seeing bears in increasing numbers, and in 1988 a visitor photographed a female with three young cubs in the Chisos Mountains. Observations increased in the 1990s, and in 1996 visitors reported 572 sightings in one year! Today, visitors regularly observe bears throughout the Chisos Mountains, and sometimes even in the desert areas of the park. The recolonization of the black bears in Big Bend is truly a remarkable natural event.
audioDescription: At this location is a metal sign that talks about what to do if a person encounters a black bear and what to do if one encounters a mountain lion. The basic message is the same for both animals: make yourself look big, yell, wave your arms around, and do not run.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #20
listingDescription: This is the twentieth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. This location affords a great view of the road into the Chisos Basin and a view out through the Window.

images.altText: From this viewpoint one can look down on the Basin and out the Window to the low desert.
images.title: View through the Window
images.caption: View out the Window

bodyText: As you traverse these switchbacks, take a moment to turn and look at the view into the Chisos Basin. With your eyes, follow the paved road as it enters the Basin and you should be able to make out the features of the campground. Past the campground is a fantastic view through the Window into the desert beyond. The Window is framed by Amon Carter Peak on the left and Vernon Bailey Peak on the right. Amon Carter (1879-1955) played an influential role in the creation of Big Bend National Park. Vernon Bailey (1864-1942) was a naturalist employed by the Bureau of Biological Survey who conducted biological surveys in Big Bend around 1901.
audioDescription: This viewpoint affords a view of the Chisos Basin, the Window, and the lower desert beyond the Window. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #21
listingDescription: This is the twenty first stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. At this stop listen to the birds around you and learn about the Rufous-crowned Sparrow.

images.altText: A small bird with a brown crown, brown eyeline, and black line on the chin sits on a small limb.
images.title: Rufous-crowned Sparrow
images.caption: Rufous-crowned Sparrow

bodyText: One of the more common birds heard and seen in the Chisos Mountains is the rufous-crowned sparrow. A larger sparrow, at six inches in length, rufous-crowned sparrows are an easier sparrow to identify. Look for an orange-brown (rufous) colored crown, a brown stripe behind the eye, a black throat-stripe, and a plain gray breast. Their call is a nasal, laughing deer deer deer deer, while their song is a husky, mumbled, descending chatter. They are usually solitary and are normally seen on the ground or in low bushes.
audioDescription: This location has a series of rocks that make great benches to sit and listen to the surrounding animal activity. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #22
listingDescription: This is the twenty second stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we look at and discuss the evergreen sumac.

images.altText: A shrub with smooth oval leaves and a waxy finish about 1.5 inches long.
images.title: Evergreen Sumac
images.caption: Evergreen sumac leaves

bodyText: Evergreen sumac has shiny green leaves virtually year-round. It is not a true evergreen, as its leaves are green through the winter, then are dropped, to be replaced with a new crop. Its fragrant white flowers attract bees and butterflies in late summer, and birds and other wildlife eat the fuzzy red-orange berries in the fall. Indigenous peoples made a drink from the tart berries.
audioDescription: The evergreen sumac is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #23
listingDescription: This is the twenty third stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. At this location you have a chance to admire and study the beautiful Texas madrone.

images.altText: A tree with red bark, small green leaves and small red berries is growing along a cliff side.
images.title: Texas Madrone tree
images.caption: Texas madrone

bodyText: Texas madrone is one of the most distinctive trees in the Chisos Mountains. Its old bark peels off in thin sheets each year, revealing smooth white bark that later turns pink or red. Red berries, which mature in November, are highly favored by deer which often rise up on their hind legs to reach them. The berries are also eaten by bear, birds, and other mammals.
audioDescription: The madrone is located next to a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny areas.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #24
listingDescription: This is stop number twenty four on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. This high elevation location offers a great view to the west, and is a great place to judge air quality on any particular day.

images.altText: A view through a "V" in the mountains affords views of the desert many miles away.
images.title: View through the Window
images.caption: Can you see buildings in the town of Terlingua?

bodyText: Turn around and look towards the Window. This high location sometimes affords a fantastic view of the desert and the towns of Study Butte and Terlingua to the west of the park. Air quality determines how much you can see on any given day. On days with great air quality, roads and buildings in the towns just outside the park are visible. On fair air quality days, such as the day when this picture was taken, it is not possible to see the towns, and there is a noticeable haze in the air. Poor air quality days make it impossible to see any features or landforms through the Window. It's as if you were trying to view the far mountains through a glazed window.
audioDescription: This location affords a long-ranging view to the west through the "V" in the Chisos Mountains. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #25
listingDescription: This is stop number twenty four on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. A rock pillar next to the trail is adorned with lichens of different colors.

images.altText: A tall reddish-brown rock pillar is spattered with yellow, white, and orange lichen.
images.title: Lichen
images.caption: Colorful lichen

bodyText: The white, yellow, and orange lichen on the rock pillars at this location consist of a fungus and an algae in a sumbiotic relationship. Because they absorb nutrients from rainwater, lichen are particularly vulnerable to air pollution. Sulfates, in particular - the predominant form of air pollution in the Big Bend region - kill the algae, so dead lichen are an early warning sign of harmful air pollution. Studying lichen can tell us about the levels and types of air pollution. Look for more colorful lichen on the rocks and trees as you continue your hike.
audioDescription: A large reddish-colored pillar of rock is covered with red, white, and yellow lichen. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #26
listingDescription: This is the final stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Enjoy the 360 degree views!

images.altText: A large rock formation juts above the surrounding terrain and distant mountains loom behind it.
images.title: End of Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: View from the end of the the Lost Mine Trail

bodyText: You have reached the end of the Lost Mine Trail. Lost Mine Peak, at 7,650 feet in elevation, dominates the skyline to the north across Upper Pine Canyon. The peak's name comes from an old legend that describes how Spanish explorers found a vein of silver in this area and enslaved local people to mine it. According to legend, the workers eventually rebelled, killed their enslavers, and sealed the mine entrance to prevent further exploitation. There is no evidence to support this legend, and geologists don't believe that silver would form in the rocks of the Chisos Mountains. However, the name adds an air of mystery to this mountain.
audioDescription: The trail ends here on a high rock outcropping. Views are possible in all directions, including views of the Chisos Mountains and the desert lowlands to the east. A large rock pinnacle stands directly at the end of the trail with a distinctive shape reminiscent of a dragon's head and long neck.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #3
listingDescription: This is the third stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we discuss characteristics of the Alligator Juniper.

images.altText: A gray tree trunk show a pattern of bark that resembles the hide of an alligator.
images.title: Alligator Juniper Bark
images.caption: Bark pattern of the Alligator Juniper

bodyText: Note how the bark of the alligator juniper is squared off in sections, resembling an alligator's hide. This is the largest of the three species of junipers found in the Chisos Mountains. The largest specimen found in the park is nearly eight feet in diameter. You will see the other two species further along the trail.
audioDescription: The alligator juniper is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #4
listingDescription: This is the fourth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we discuss the Mexican drooping juniper, found only in west Texas.

images.altText: The leaves of the drooping juniper hang downwards off the branches, as if they were wilted.
images.title: Drooping Juniper
images.caption: Notice the droop of the leaves off the branches

bodyText: The Mexican drooping juniper, or weeping juniper, is the most common juniper in Mexico, but in the United States it is found only in the mountains of West Texas. The major portion of its range is in Mexio and extends from Chihuahua south to Oaxaca and Guatemala. It always appears wilted, no matter how much rainfall it receives. The tree usually grows 25 to 30 feet tall, although it can be up to 55 feet in height.
audioDescription: The Mexican drooping juniper is located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #5
listingDescription: This is the fifth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here the trail crosses over a culvert built with native rocks by the Civilian Conservation Corps.

images.altText: A dirt hiking trail crosses over a culvert built from local stone by the Civilian Conservation Corps
images.title: Culvert Built by the CCC
images.caption: Culvert built by the CCC

bodyText: The Civilian Conservation Corps built this stone culvert, rock walls, and other masonry structures along the trail. From 1934 through 1937, the first group of CCC workers surveyed and laid out the Basin Road using only hand tools and a dump truck. In the process, they moved 40,000 cubic yards of earth and 5,000 yards of solid rock. The stone culverts along the this trail and the road are excellent examples of their craftsmanship. From 1940 to 1942, a second group of CCC built the stone cottages that are located up behind the main lodge rooms in the Chisos Basin.
audioDescription: A dirt path makes a bend and passes over a shallow drainage. Rock walls and a culvert allow the path to pass over the drainage. Grasses and cacti cover the open areas that are not shaded by trees.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #6
listingDescription: This is the sixth stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here one has the chance to examine several agave that have not yet grown their famous stalk.

images.altText: Two plants with wide, thick gray leaves growing out of a central base are located next to a trail.
images.title: Agave
images.caption: Two agave buddies

bodyText: Agaves, or century plants, grow for many years before reproducing. Some may do so as quickly as 20 years, while other will wait 40 years before deciding it's time. In their final month, they will put all their energy into producing a huge flowering stalk that can grow up to 15 feet tall. Their yellow flowers attract nectar-feeding bats, hummingbirds, and many types of insects. Birders searching for the Lucifer Hummingbird, found only in west Texas and southeastern AZ, would do well to closely watch the agave. Sadly, the plant dies after blooming. Similar species of agave are commercially grown in Mexico to make tequila.
audioDescription: These agave are located alongside a dirt hiking trail. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #7
listingDescription: This is the seventh stop on the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Here we discuss grasses and the benefits of wildfire.

images.altText: Grasses and a few trees cover a hillside
images.title: Mountain grasses and Casa Grande
images.caption: Grass-covered slope below Casa Grande

bodyText:
Stipa grass, grama grass, and other grasses grow abundantly in certain parts of the Chisos Mountains. They supported the ranching industry that flourished here in the early 1900s. Today these grasses provide food for deer and smaller wildlife, and help hold fragile soil in place.
Periodic wildfires help to maintain this ecosystem of grasses and trees; grass fires return nutrients to the soil and create clearings for tree seedlings to grow. Without fires, brush accumulates and chokes out seedlings and grasses, changing the overall ecology of the mountains.
audioDescription: At this stop we focus on the different grasses covering the nearby hillside. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #8
listingDescription: This is the eighth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-guided Tour. Wooden benches at this location make it a great place to rest and listen to the birds singing.

images.altText: A bird with a white chest and bright blue back sits on a small tree limb.
images.title: Mexican Jay
images.caption: Mexican Jay

bodyText: These wooden benches are located about 0.75 miles from the trailhead. This is a great location to take a break and listen to the birds singing around you. Many of the songs you hear are pleasant, but you may have noticed one call in particular that is best described as harsh. A fairly high-pitched, nasal, repeating weenk weenk weenk is the most commonly heard call of the Mexican Jay. Mexican Jays live in family groups of up to 25 individuals and may have several active nests in one territory. All group members share the responsibility of feeding young. They rarely disperse and stay with their groups throughout their lives. Their range extends from Mexico into pine-oak-juniper woodlands of the southwestern United States, including west Texas.
audioDescription: Two wooden benches are located along the trail in a shady spot beneath large trees. The surrounding hillsides are covered with other trees including oak, pine, and juniper and shrubs such as sage, mountain mahogany, and sumac. Grasses and cacti cover the open, sunny slopes.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lost Mine Trail Stop #9
listingDescription: This is the fifth stop along the Lost Mine Trail Self-Guided Tour. This location affords a great view of Casa Grande, Vernon Bailey Peak, and the Chisos Basin.

images.altText: A light fog makes the forest look damp and very green.
images.title: Fog in the Trees
images.caption: Foggy day in the Chisos Mountains

bodyText: 10,000 years ago the climate in Big Bend was cooler and wetter, and the woodland ecosystem around you would have covered the landscape as far as the eye can see. As the climate slowly became warmer and drier, the woodland species could no longer survive in the lower elevations, and more desert-adapted species moved in to take their place. Today, mountains like the Chisos protect small relict populations of once-widespread plants, animals, and other organisms that are isolated here by the surrounding desert.
audioDescription: From this vantage point, one has a great view looking back down into the Chisos Basin. The jagged peaks of the Chisos Mountains provide a dramatic background to the lower, grassy slopes that compose the shallow Basin.

quickFacts.value: Lost Mine Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff Trail
listingDescription: The Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff Trail is an easy walk along a drainage to a pouroff that is dry most of the year. The trail is family-friendly and is particularly enticing for those interested in plants or geology.

images.altText: A gravel path starts at a trailhead sign and winds back to colorful igneous cliffs.
images.title: Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff Trailhead
images.caption: The Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff trailhead.

bodyText:
Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 1.0 mile (1.6 km)
Elevation Change: 120 feet (36 m)
Average hiking time: 30 minutes

Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

The Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff Trail is a relatively flat, easy hike to a pouroff that is dry most of the year. A good portion of the trail follows a gravel wash lined by Mexican persimmon, Mexican buckeye, and desert hackberry trees. The wash is bounded by volcanic hills with layers of yellow and orange ash-flow tuffs. Large congomerate boulders litter the valley bottom. The trail ends at the pouroff—a 100-foot tall vertical channel carved into rock that funnels water from the mesa above.

During the rainy season, flashfloods may race down the wash. Be careful and don't get caught in the canyon during a storm.

Accessibility

The upper part of the trail is a fairly flat dirt and rock path. After about 0.25 miles, the trail descends into the wash via a series of uneven steps. The wash is gently-sloped, coarse sand and gravel. 
The trailhead is at the end of a paved road. Sixteen pull-in parking spaces and one handicap spot offer plenty of parking.

Hike Smart

Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed, or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.
audioDescription: A trailhead sign at the beginning of the trail reads: "The Lower Burro Mesa Pouroff trail is an easy walk that leads through a gravel creek bed to a narrow box canyon where water has carved a deep channel into Burro Mesa. This 100-foot pouroff attests to the power of water that floods this canyon during summer rains. Burro Mesa gives evidence of Big Bend's volcanic past. The yellow and orange bands across the bluffs are ash-flow tuffs, which show the layered beds crated as they were deposited. The top of the cliff is formed from Burro Mesa Rhyolite. Pouroffs are seasonal waterfalls. During rainy times water might flow through these drainages in powerful flash floods, continuing to carve the channel. Without much permeable soil to soak in to, the water continues downhill quickly, often with the flow ending within a few hours after a rainstorm. Water might continue to slowly flow beneath the surface of the gravel creek bed, causing water to seep down the face of the pouroff for days before drying again."

quickFacts.value: 11 miles from the northern end of the Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Geology
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Luna's Jacal
listingDescription: Luna's Jacal was the residence of Gilberto Luna, a pioneer Mexican farmer who made a living in this remote area by goat-herding and farming along the moist banks of Alamo Creek. The jacal, a low dugout dwelling, is a great example of a primitive Mexican house-shelter characteristic of early pioneer settlement in the Big Bend area.

images.altText: Luna's Jacal
images.title: Luna's Jacal
images.caption: Explore a small historic dugout house from the early days of Big Bend.

bodyText:
Luna's Jacal was the residence of Gilberto Luna, a pioneer Mexican farmer who made a living in this remote area by goatherding and farming along the moist banks of Alamo Creek. He sold goats to his neighbors and nearby miners, and he also sold wood cut in the Chisos. Luna was a well-respected resident and known far and wide throughout the Big Bend.

The jacal (hah-KAHL), a low dugout dwelling, is a great example of a primitive Mexican house-shelter characteristic of early pioneer settlement in the Big Bend area. The house backs up to a large boulder and is remarkably suited to the desert environment. The roof was made of ocotillo branches weighted down with earth and stones.

Luna arrived in 1916, and raised a large family at this site. His farm was one of several along Alamo Creek. His house still stands as a testament to his impressive ability to adapt to the harsh environment of the region and to his diplomatic skills in a frontier and border society. 
 

A wayside exhibit panel nearby offers more information about Luna and his family.
audioDescription: A small house, rectangular shaped, approximately 10 feet by 25 feet. The rear of the house uses a large flat boulder as one end. The walls are limestone rocks stacked up to 4 feet high. The roof is made of ocotillo branches and brush, held up by wooden log beams. The structure is significant as the prime example within the park of primitive houses constructed by the early pioneers. The house is located adjacent to the road, along the edge of Alamo wash. Behind the house, Pena Mountain rises dramatically.

quickFacts.value: Luna's Jacal is located at the base of Pena Mountain, 6 miles from the southern end of the Maverick Road in Big Bend National Park. The road is gravel, and may become impassable after rains.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Gilberto Luna built this small dwelling and lived here until 1947. Luna was well-known and respected among the residents of the Big Bend.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Magdalena House
listingDescription: The Magdalena House is an addition to the Castolon Compound, built after the military left Camp Santa Helena. Magdalena Silvas lived in this house in the 1950s as a widowed mother who raised her five children while cooking for La Harmonia Company here in Castolon for about 30 years.

images.altText: Adobe Structure with Ramada, Magdalena House
images.title: Magdalena House
images.caption: Magdalena House in the Castolon Historic District

bodyText: The Magdalena House is an addition to the Castolon Compound, built after the military left Camp Santa Helena. Magdalena Silvas lived and worked in the Castolon area for over 30 years. In the 1950s Magdalena moved to this house from one down the bluff. Here she continued to raise her five children as a widowed mother, while working as a cook for the La Harmonia Company. She also washed and ironed clothes. Later, the house served as the home and office for government employees after inclusion in Big Bend National Park. The Magdalena House now features exhibits about life in Castolon around 100 years ago.
audioDescription: A one-story adobe house with a peaked tin roof with has two front doors and a bench out front. A statue of a baby goat and three chickens are arranged in front of the house. Other historic buildings of adobe and wood dating from the 1920s are nearby, as well as a temporary building housing a concession store. The surrounding desert landscape is composed of cacti, creosote bushes, and low grasses. Text on the exhibit panel in front of Magdelena House: Magdalena Silvas lived in this house in the 1950s. As a widowed mother, she raised her five children while cooking for La Harmonia Company here in Castolon for about 30 years. The family kept animals in the yard. The Magdalena House is a window into the early 20th century of the Rio Grande region- Mexican and U.S. citizens created a bicultural, binational agricultural community defined by the river and isolation. Spanish Translation: La casa de Magdalena Magdalena Silvas vivió en esta casa durante la década de 1950. Siendo una madre viuda, crió a su cinco hijos mientras trabajaba cocinando para la companía La Harmonía aquí en Castolon por aproximadamente 30 años. La familia mantenía a los animales en el patio. La casa de Magdalena es una ventana hacia los incios del siglo XX en la región del Río Bravo del Norte- los cuidadanos mexicanos y estadounidenses formaron una comunidad agrícola bicultural y binacional que estaba delimitada por el río y el aislamiento.

quickFacts.value: Along Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive in Big Bend National Park, Texas
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Castolon Historic District represents the largest and most complex example of human history in Big Bend, where the cultures of Mexico and the United States of America met in one rural community along the border.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: U.S. National Register of Historic Places, U.S. Historic District, HABS
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Mariscal Canyon Rim Trail
listingDescription: The 6.5 mile Mariscal Rim Trail is as rewarding as it is remote. Located in the very southern part of the park along River Road, it takes 2 hours to reach the trailhead from the paved park road near Rio Grande Village. A high-clearance, 4x4 vehicle is necessary to reach the trailhead.

images.altText: Two hikers peer over the edge of a high limestone cliff.
images.title: Mariscal Canyon Rim Trail
images.caption: Viewing the Rio Grande 1,400 feet below

bodyText:
Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 6.5 miles (10.5 km) 
Elevation change: 1,300 feet (396 m)
Average hiking time: 3-4 hours

Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

The Mariscal Canyon Rim Trail is as rewarding as it is remote. Located in the very southern part of the park along River Road, it takes 2 hours to reach the trailhead from the paved park road near Rio Grande Village. A high-clearance, 4x4 vehicle is necessary to reach the trailhead.  
Views are magnificent as you ascend the western slopes of Mariscal Mountain. You can see the park's expansive low desert, and the mountains stretching far off into Mexico. Mariscal Canyon itself is difficult to see until you arrive at the rim, and suddenly encounter the deep precipice.

Accessibility

The route crosses open desert for approximately 1.5 miles before steeply ascending to the rim. Notice: Hikers must be prepared for the challenges of this trail. Temperatures may well exceed 110°F during spring and summer. You will find NO shade and NO water along this trail. This combination of factors make this trail potentially deadly during the late spring and summer. Tell someone your plans before heading out.

Hike Smart

Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.
audioDescription: The hike to the rim of Mariscal Canyon provides hikers the opportunity to peer into the most remote of the three canyons in the park. The trail climbs a mountain composed of limestone, which is thinly covered in desert vegetation including cacti, lechuguilla, and cholla. 1,300 feet below, the river is a band of green providing life-giving water in a parched land. Distant views into Mexico showcase the mountains found on the other side of the Rio Grande.

quickFacts.value: 2 hour drive from the start of East River Road
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mariscal Mine
listingDescription: Abandoned since the 1940s, and isolated by its remote location in the middle of Big Bend National Park, the Mariscal Mine is the best preserved mercury mining site in the state of Texas, and is a listed historic district on the National Register of Historic Places.

images.altText: Morning light at the Mariscal Mine
images.title: Morning light at the Mariscal Mine
images.caption: Morning light at the Mariscal Mine

bodyText:
The Mariscal Mine once bustled as the center of the Big Bend quicksilver mining economy. From 1900 to 1943, Mariscal Mine produced 1,400 seventy-six pound flasks of mercury - nearly one quarter of the total produced in the United States! Now deserted, the mine and surroundings once provided the people who lived here an income, a community, and a home.

A visit to Mariscal Mine conjures up images of hard-working men, women, and machines. With a little imagination, you can get a feeling for the work of these early pioneers and their contributions to Big Bend's rich human history. The remains of the mine stand today as a symbol of a time when "quicksilver was king" and as a vivid reminder of the cycle of human activities and nature's reclamation.

The mine is located on the northern end of Mariscal Mountain, deep in the interior of Big Bend National Park. Easiest access to the area is via the River Road east, which begins just west of Rio Grande Village. The mine is located approximately 22 miles down the gravel road. This is a remote and primitive dirt road. A high clearance vehicle (with at least 8 inches of clearance or more from the lowest point of the frame, body, suspension, or differential, to the ground) is always required, and after any rains, the road will require four-wheel drive. Always check with a park ranger for current road conditions before setting out. Allow at least one-half day for this excursion.

Safety Precautions and Regulations

While exploring the area, remember to leave all objects in place in the park; collecting is prohibited. Because they are old, fragile, and unsafe, please stay off of the remaining structures. Avoid handling the bricks of the Scott Furnace and condensers or handling mine tailings as they may contain poisonous concentrations of mercury. Finally, be careful around the mine shafts; although most are fenced, they are vertical and deep, and other unfenced shafts may exist in the area.

Learn more about the Mariscal Mine:

Mariscal Mine - Big Bend National Park
audioDescription: Abandoned since the 1940s, and isolated by its remote location in the middle of Big Bend National Park, the Mariscal Mine is the best preserved mercury mining site in the state of Texas, and is a listed historic district on the National Register of Historic Places. From the parking area, a rugged trail leads uphill for 1/2 mile through the ruins of the mine. Stone buildings, condenser piping, rubble, and assorted mining equipment still remain. Views in all directions are spectacular. Several mine shafts exist throughout the site, and visitors must be vigilant and careful while exploring the site.

quickFacts.value: 22 miles along the remote and primitive River Road
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Historic Mining District
quickFacts.name: Significance
