title: Marufo Vega / Ore Terminal Trails
listingDescription: Three trails start at this point on the Boquillas Canyon road. The 14-mile Marufo Vega trail, the 8-mile Ore Terminal trail, and the 14-mile Strawhouse Trail. All of these trails are best experienced in temperatures below 80 degrees (26 Celcius).

images.altText: A metal sign with trail information sits beside a dirt path heading into the mountains.
images.title: Marufo Vega Trailhead
images.caption: Beginning location for three different trails

bodyText:
Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

Three trails begin from this trailhead.

One, the Marufo Vega trail, is a rough ascent into the Dead Horse mountains that features a loop, a portion of which parallels the rim of Boquillas Canyon. The trail plus the loop is approximately 14 miles (22 km) in length, with about 3,800 feet (1,158 meters) of cumulative elevation change.

The second trail that branches off is the Ore Terminal Trail, which follows the route of the ore tramway that came from the Puerto Rico mine in Mexico to the terminal at the top of a ridge above Ernst Valley. This trail is about 8 miles (13 km) in length, with about 800 feet (244 meters) of elevation change.

The third trail is the Strawhouse Trail, which terminates at the Telephone Canyon Trail to the north. This Strawhouse Trail is about 14 miles (22 km) one-way, with about 1,600 feet (487 meters) of elevation change.

All of these trails are best experienced in temperatures below 80 degrees (26 Celcius).
 

Accessibility

These three trails traverse rocky ground covered in loose pebbles, making it necessary to place your feet with care. In addition, all of these trails involve large elevation changes - hiking poles are recommended to assist with balance.

The dirt parking lot provides parking for about 5 vehicles.

Hike Smart
Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.
audioDescription: The Marufo Vega trailhead is the start of three rough trails into the Dead Horse mountains. The views include the Dead Horse and Sierra del Carmen mountains and the large hills along the Rio Grande. The vegetation is typical of the Chihuahuan desert and include lechugilla, creosote bush, prickly pear and mesquite.

quickFacts.value: 2.5 miles down Boquillas Canyon Road
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Maverick Entrance
listingDescription: A Big Bend National Park sign welcomes visitors entering the park from the west side, near the towns of Study Butte and Terlingua.

images.altText: A stone and concrete sign with Big Bend's title sits adjacent to a paved vehicle pullout.
images.title: Maverick Entrance Sign
images.caption: Park sign on the west side of the park

bodyText: This park sign marks the western entrance to Big Bend National Park. Situated at the base of colorful clay hills, with the Chisos Mountains rising up in the distance, this is a great location to take that classic park sign photo.
audioDescription: A stone and concrete sign rests next a pullout along the highway. The following words are placed on the concrete using metal letters: Big Bend National Park, Rio Grande Wild and Scenic River, a U.S. Biosphere Reserve. On the right side of the sign, on the stone is a large brown National Park Service arrowhead. Behind the sign are a series of colorful clay hills, which the highway climbs to the entrance station. Behind the hills, further in the distance are the towering cliffs of the Chisos Mountains. The highest peak in the park, Emory Peak (7,825 feet) is located directly west of this location.

quickFacts.value: 3 miles east of the town of Study Butte, TX
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Maverick Entrance Station
listingDescription: This is the entrance station on the west side of the park near the towns of Study Butte and Terlingua. Visitors pay an entrance fee which is valid for 7 days, and are given a park map and newspaper.

images.altText: A small adobe building sits between two lanes of highway, with a flagpole and stop sign nearby.
images.title: Maverick Entrance Station
images.caption: Park fees collected and maps/information provided at this location

bodyText: This entrance station is situated just inside the western boundary of the park, close to the towns of Study Butte and Terlingua. Visitors to the park can pay the entrance fee, purchase park passes and receive the park map and newspaper at this location. If park personnel are not present at the entrance station, visitors can pay the entrance fee and acquire a window tag at the Panther Junction or Chisos Basin visitor centers.
audioDescription: A small, light-colored adobe building sits in the middle of the highway, with the two opposite lanes of traffic dividing around it. Off in the distance the high Chisos Mountains dominate the skyline. Pulling up at the stop sign next to the building, visitors are greeted by a park ranger through a window.

quickFacts.value: 4 miles east of the town of Study Butte, TX
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Maverick Information Board
listingDescription: This information board, along with a restroom, are located near the Maverick Entrance Station on the west end of the park.

images.altText: A covered bulletin board with three panels sits next to an ocotillo, with a mountain behind.
images.title: Maverick Bulletin Board
images.caption: Trip planning information and park notices posted here

bodyText: Almost immediately after passing through the Maverick Entrance Station, you'll see a parking lot on the right side of the road. This parking area contains a vault toilet and a large bulletin board with a map and information about things to do in the park. This is a great opportunity to orient yourself in the vastness of this 800,000 acre park, and decide where to go next.
audioDescription: From the Maverick parking area, a view to the east reveals the large bulk of the Chisos Mountains, towering over the desert. To the south, one can see the 1,500 feet deep Santa Elena Canyon, appearing as if a doorway through a line of cliffs. To the north, it's possible to follow the paved road as it passes through desert flats of ocotillo, creosotebush, and cactus. Text on the bulletin boards: Big Bend in Close-up - From a vehicle, the desert flats can appear lifeless. On foot, your focus shifts and an unseen wilderness comes to life with a rasping of locusts and a trickling of sand down a tiny burrow. After visiting the park's major features, change your mode of touring; become a desert rat for a while. Dugout Wells is a good place to start, where an oasis punctuates the sun-baked dazzle of the Chihuahuan Desert Nature Trail. Or improvise your own trails: flash floods are rarely witnessed, but by walking any dry wash you can discover the dramatic results - the tumbled boulders and brief outburst of wildflowers. You can reduce Big Bend's giant-scale geology to human scale by hiking park trails such as Tuff Canyon, Santa Elena Canyon or the "Window". Big Bend National Park - From the rim of the cool, pine-scented Chisos Mountains, you can gaze across most of the park to distant mountain ranges in Mexico. From the depths of Santa Elena Canyon you can see only a thin ribbon of sky. A drive across Big Bend is also a vertical journey through sharply contrasting environments, an adventure for the perceptions. By walking one of the many short trails you can begin to discover the park's hidden life. Cactus flowers bloom from desert hardpan that is pocked with mysterious burrows. Painted buntings, summer tanagers, and other bird species that winter in the tropics next along the lush banks of the Rio Grande. At Big Bend, time has many dimensions. An abandoned ranch along Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive can evoke an entire era. At the Fossil Discovery Exhibit, prehistoric mammal bones are clues to the park's tropical past.

quickFacts.value: 0.1 mile east of Maverick Entrance Station
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #1
listingDescription: One mile up the road is the Panther Junction Visitor Center where one can get maps, information and orientation. There is also a Post Office, restrooms, and a short 0.25 mile nature trail.

images.altText: A large agave is growing in front of a square building with a NPS arrowhead on the side of the wall.
images.title: Panther Junction Visitor Center
images.caption: Havard agave growing in front of visitor center

bodyText:
The Panther Junction Visitor Center is one mile ahead. There you may obtain further information and orientation. A ranger can answer your questions and help plan your visit. Publications for sale and free brochures deal with almost every aspect of the park. You will also find a post office, restrooms, and a short 0.25 mile nature trail. A gas station is located 1/8 mile to the west of the visitor center. 
You are halfway into the park. In all directions a fascinating and varied land awaits your discovery. We are proud of the diverse natural and cultural resources in Big Bend and ask you to assist us by reporting any illegal collecting activity. 
Have a safe and enjoyable visit!
audioDescription: Just ahead the outlines of a building take shape. The visitor center parking lot will accommodate a vehicle of any size. From this location, three roads depart - east to Rio Grande Village, west towards the Chisos Mountains and Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive, and north back the direction you just drove. No matter where you are in the park, one always has a view of the Chisos Mountains - considered to be the heart of Big Bend National Park.

quickFacts.value: 1mile north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #10
listingDescription: This section of the road, between Mile Markers 8 and 10, offers a great view of the colorful clay hills often referred to as badlands.

images.altText: Low hills composed of colorful clay dominate a desert landscape.
images.title: Badlands
images.caption: A colorful addition to Tornillo Flat

bodyText: You are now approaching a bizarre landscape characterized by clay hills, hoodoos, and a colorful maze of gullies. Such areas are often called "badlands." Badlands most often develop in semiarid climates where impervious clay or shale rocks alternate with layers of sandstone. These areas contain little vegetation, making it hard for the ground to soak up the brief, but heavy rainfall associated with isolated thunderstorms. The variety of features here show the result of erosion carving both the hard and soft rock layers, some of which are nearly horizontal while others dip at steep angles. The different colors result from minerals and weathering of the rocks.
audioDescription: Most of the "badlands" are located on the right side of the road. In the morning, when the sun is low and soft, the pink, purple, orange, and brown colors in the clay hills seem to glow. Here and there, these hills are overlain with a harder sandstone layer, protecting the softer clay layer from erosion. Some of these sandstone layers contain "hoodoos", or balancing pinnacles of rock that resemble structures, animals or fanciful objects.

quickFacts.value: 10 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #11
listingDescription: The land surrounding the road shows evidence of efforts to restore native grasses to Tornillo Flat. This area of the park was stripped of vegetation by overgrazing in the 1930s and 1940s, before it was a national park.

images.altText: Lines of dead vegetation are laid out on the bare desert soil, in hopes of catching runoff from rain
images.title: Restoring Grasslands
images.caption: Evidence of grassland restoration efforts

bodyText:
You are approaching an area known as Tornillo Flat, a long plain formed by the erosive action of Tornillo Creek and its tributaries. Prior to 1920, settlers describe Tornillo Flat as a grassland covered by tobosa grass. Pronghorn once ran here over the grassy flats. This grassland provided some of the best range in West Texas, allowing for the birth and growth of successful ranches.

However, decades of overgrazing by livestock began to eliminate the grasses. Drought killed what remained. Once the protective grass cover was removed, erosion stripped the precious topsoil away and the land lost its ability to hold water. 

Can damaged lands be restored? The National Park Service has taken on the challenge of restoring native grasses with a long-term project called "Grasslands Not Badlands." Over the years, and through trial and error, park staff have researched and developed different techniques to encourage growth of native grass species. A successful method has evolved to lay lines of dead vegetation perpendicular to the flow of water across the landscape. These strips slow the flow of run off after it rains and let the soil absorb more moisture. This technique is visible on both sides of the road between mile markers 11 and 10.
audioDescription: Between mile markers 11 and 10, one has a good view of the sparsely vegetated flatlands surrounding the road. There are numerous areas where the ground is completely bare of living plants. In these bare areas, long lines of dead plant material such as branches and root balls have been laid out perpendicular to the direction water would flow. These piles have also been placed in depressions and other low areas where water might gather. If you didn't know otherwise, you might suppose that dead plant material was naturally deposited in those areas from gravity and rain. To the west of the road, one has their last good view of the Rosillos Mountains before leaving them behind.

quickFacts.value: 11 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #12
listingDescription: Approaching from the north, the Chisos Mountains seem to rise higher and higher the closer you drive. The highest point in the park is found at the top of Emory Peak at 7,825 feet (2,385 meters).

images.altText: A line of high mountains fills the skyline behind a mixture of grassland and desert vegetation.
images.title: Chisos Mountains
images.caption: View of the Chisos Mountains from the north

bodyText:
The group of high mountains directly in front of you is known as the Chisos Mountains. Formed about 42 million years ago, some of the Chisos Mountain peaks share an origin similar to the Rosillos'. Emory Peak, the highest point in the park, and the third highest mountain in the state of Texas, rises 7,825 feet (2,385 meters) above sea level.

Legend suggests that the word Chisos means "ghost-like." Distance, weather, and lightning sometimes combine to cause these mountains to take on such characteristics. A more popular belief holds that Chisoz, later spelled Chisos, is a Spanish pluralization of the Apachean word chishi which means "people of the forest." A forest, you ask? How could there be a forest in the desert? Take a drive up to the Chisos Basin and discover for yourself a forested island in a sea of desert.
audioDescription: Looking south, the direction the road is headed, one has a great view of the peaks of the Chisos Mountains rising from the low desert. From this distance, it is easy to pick out the highest point, Emory Peak. As you drive closer, Emory Peak recedes behind the other high points that are closer to the forefront. The fact that each peak looks so different from the others, combined with their jagged contours, is evidence of the volcanic origins of these mountains. No two look alike!

quickFacts.value: 12 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #14
listingDescription: One mile ahead is a turn-off for the Dagger Flat Road. This is a 14-mile round-trip drive down a dirt road - high clearance necessary - to view a unique forest of giant dagger yuccas.

images.altText: A hillside is covered with yuccas in full bloom, showing off their large white blossoms.
images.title: Dagger Yuccas
images.caption: Giant dagger yuccas in bloom

bodyText: About one mile ahead the Dagger Flat Road begins on your left. A 14-mile round-trip drive down this dirt road provides the opportunity to view a unique forest of giant dagger yuccas. Along the way one can get a closer look at the plants, and possibly animals, found in the Chihuahuan Desert. The best time of the year to view the dagger yuccas blooming is in late spring, specifically April and May. The road has sandy and rocky areas that may present challenges after a rain. The first two miles of the drive are suitable for any vehicle, but a high clearance vehicle is recommended for the remaining six miles. Allow at least two hours to complete the entire tour. Nineteen numbered markers along the route correspond to the Dagger Flat Self-Guided Tour found on this app.
audioDescription: This dirt road begins in the lower desert found along the drive between Panther Junction and Persimmon Gap. The first 2 miles of the drive are on an improved dirt road suitable for any vehicle, but the remaining 6 miles could be challenging in a vehicle with low clearance. The vegetation along the first half of this drive is typical of lower elevations, with creosotebush, lechuguilla, cacti, ocotillo, and cholla. As the road gains elevation, different plants such as persimmon tree, littleleaf leadtree, mesquite, and yuccas become more prominent. The drive ends in an enclosed valley that hosts thousands of giant dagger yucca. These yucca can be over 12 feet tall and in the spring their enormous white blooms decorate the hills like flaming candlesticks.

quickFacts.value: 14 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #15
listingDescription: The Dead Horse Mountains stretch along the horizon to the east. This mountain range formed from sediments deposited by the last sea to cover this area, millions of years ago.

images.altText: Large sotol plants dominate the bottom of a drainage that is surrounded by limestone hills.
images.title: Dead Horse Mountains
images.caption: Canyon in the Dead Horse Mountains

bodyText: The Dead Horse Mountains stretch along the horizon to your left. Remote, rugged, and dry, they remain the least explored part of the park. The Dead Horse are part of a larger range, the Sierra del Carmen, which extend into Mexico. The limestone in these mountains formed from sediments deposited by the last sea to cover this area. Millions of years later, the birth of the Rocky Mountains raised this land. Intense pressure uplifted and tilted great blocks of earth including the Sierra del Carmen and Dead Horse Mountain ranges. The Rio Grande cuts across this uplifted block, carving Boquillas Canyon, one of the park's three great canyons, with walls 1,200 feet high.
audioDescription: Looking off to the east (left side of the road), one has a view of a line of rounded mountains extending roughly parallel to the road. They appear as one unbroken ridgeline, but they are in fact cut by numerous canyons. These canyons branch off into dry drainages, some of which are quite wide, and appear like long valleys between the higher ridges. Little water is present in these drainages, except following infrequent rains, so typical desert vegetation predominates.

quickFacts.value: 15 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #16
listingDescription: On normal days, one has great views of the Chisos Mountains from this mile marker. Other days, the air quality is so bad that you can barely see them. Why is this?

images.altText: A line of mountains in the distance is obscured by bad air quality.
images.title: Bad Air Quality
images.caption: Obscured view of the Chisos Mountains

bodyText:
How far can you see? From this mile marker, you should have a great view of the Chisos Mountains, located about 18 miles to the south. But some days the air quality is so poor that those mountains are lost in a haze of pollution. 

Over half of Big Bend's visibility impairment is due to sulfates, while organic carbons, nitrates, and wind-blown particles account for the remaining components. Sources of sulfate particles include coal-fired power plants, metal smelters, refineries, and other industrial facilities.

Air quality here varies significantly by season. Prevailing winter winds are from the north and west, while summer winds are usually from the south and east. Air masses arriving from the southeast bring the highest concentrations of sulfates and create the poorest visibility. Research indicates that, during this peak period, pollution originates from sources in the eastern United States, east Texas, and northeast Mexico. 

What can be done? The National Park Service works cooperatively with the Environmental Protection Agency, the state of Texas, and Mexico to improve visibility in Big Bend. The use of modern emission-control technology on existing pollution sources, the careful placement and control of new industry, and the involvement of concerned citizens can help to restore visiblity.
audioDescription: The Chisos Mountains rise in the distance, reaching heights of more than 4,000 feet above the surrounding landscape. From here, they appear to be nothing more than craggy, bare rock, but upon closer inspection one can see the unique plant life that is a result of their height. These forested slopes stand in stark contrast to the sotol-grasslands found in the foothills below.

quickFacts.value: 16 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #17
listingDescription: This is a good location to view typical vegetation associated with low elevations in the Chihuahuan Desert. The creosotebush is discussed, as well as other adaptations that help plants survive in this hot, dry environment.

images.altText: A close-up view of a shrub with small dark green leaves and little yellow flowers.
images.title: Creosotebush
images.caption: After rain, the desert air smells like this plant

bodyText:
The predominant shrub all around you is creosote. While most shrubs lose their leaves in winter, creosote can maintain its resinous foliage year round. During drought, the leaves will appear golden brown. After a rainstorm, the shrubs "green-up" again and often produce small yellow flowers several times a year.

The desert disciplines its inhabitants, but it is far from lifeless. In fact, over 1,200 species of plants are found here. Because the land and climate can be uncompromising, life forms have adapted in remarkable ways. Dark colors absorb too much heat, so a strategy for plants to survive in the desert is to be light-colored. At some point during your visit, look closely at the plants (but not too close) and note that most of them are armed with thorns, spines, or barbs. The needles on plants prevent animals, including humans, from bothering them. On some plants the tightly netted spines provide shade and act as a windbreak.
audioDescription: The view hasn't changed much in the last 5 miles, but the road has been slowly losing elevation, which corresponds with less vegetation. What vegetation exists is typically spread apart from each other, due to the lack of rainfall for most of the year. The creosotebush discussed at this mile marker is a uniquely suited to this environment because it secrets a toxin that keep most plants from growing next to it and competing for water.

quickFacts.value: 17 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #19
listingDescription: The view from this location encompasses the Rosillos Mountains to the west and Dagger Mountain to the east. It provides the opportunity to compare igneous mountains created by a laccolith (Rosillos), versus sedimentary limestone mountains (Dagger Mtn).

images.altText: A semicircular mountain range rises up behind a desert landscape with yucca in the foreground.
images.title: Rosillos Mountains
images.caption: View of the Rosillos from the north

bodyText: Mountains surround you. To your left is Dagger Mountain; to your right, the Rosillos Mountains stand 5,445 feet above sea level. On the distant horizon loom the Chisos Mountains lying in the heart of Big Bend National Park. The Rosillos Mountains formed as underground magma (molten rock) pushed upward but never reached the surface. The molten material bulged into a mushroom shape, coming to rest on top of older rock layers and doming the others above it. The roan-colored (rosillos in Spanish) mountains you see are composed of this igneous rock which cooled and lay far below the surface. Over time, erosion has chiseled away the overlying rock, exposing the once molten mass.
audioDescription: The three mountain ranges visible from this location are very different in size, elevation and composition. The closer Dagger Mountain on the left is mainly composed of limestone, and this is reflected in the low, rounded shape of an extensive range. The Rosillos Mountains on the right are higher, but the bulk of the mountains are arranged in a semi-circular shape, with many canyons bisecting the sides and interior. The Chisos Mountains to the north boast the highest peak in the park at 7,820 feet (2,383 meters) and rise dramatically from the lower desert. The Chisos cover a much larger area than the other two ranges and are a combination of multiple peaks created by individual volcanoes that erupted millions of years ago.

quickFacts.value: 19 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #2
listingDescription: Have you noticed a difference in the vegetation over the last few miles? At this elevation, the plants are beginning to change from desert lowlands to sotol grasslands.

images.altText: Mountainous terrain dominated by sotol, grasses, shrubs, and yellow wildflowers.
images.title: Sotol grassland
images.caption: Sotol grasslands dominate between 3,500-5,000 feet (1,066-1,524 meters)

bodyText: Have you noticed the changes in the vegetation over the last couple of miles? You are beginning to enter a higher area of Big Bend - an area that is cooler and receives more precipitation than does the previous 25 miles you have driven. Because of these conditions, the desert is giving way to a greener and more moderate habitat called the Sotol-Grassland. This habitat is typically found between 3,500 to 5,000 feet (1,066 - 1,524 meters). The sotol plant is a crowded cluster of ribbonlike leaves up to three feet long, with sawtooth margins. In April and May, the plants produce a stalk 10 to 20 feet high which gives the sotol a second name - Desert Candle. The indigenous Americans baked the "heart" of the sotol for food. Today it would be more likely to find these baked hearts fermented and distilled into a tequila--like liquor, also called sotol.
audioDescription: The vegetation in this area has become more dense and crowded. The shrubs are taller, the ground contains more grass, and typically more wildlife is present. These sotol-grasslands are found in the foothills and up the lower slopes of the Chisos Mountains, providing a green tint to the reddish-brown rocks.

quickFacts.value: 2 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #22
listingDescription: An exhibit located less than one mile down the road contains two information panels that discuss a large land addition to the park, and the influence of flash floods on the landscape.

images.altText: A map of the park shows the main roads and a section of land that was added in 1989.
images.title: Map of Big Bend
images.caption: The North Rosillos addition to the park

bodyText:
The vast acreage to your right was added to the park in 1989. Six years prior, the Harte brothers generously donated their 67,125-acre North Rosillos ranch (highlighted in green on the map) to the Nature Conservancy with intent that the land ultimately go to Big Bend National Park. It was the single largest donation since the park's establishment in 1944.
Ahead, a roadside exhibit marks Nine Point Draw. Stop and observe the surrounding landscape. Together with Bone Spring Draw, the two washes drain much of the land on your right. Though dry most of the year, a heavy rain transforms these washes into muddy, raging torrents which can roar wall to wall through Dog Canyon. The Big Bend region is crisscrossed with dry washes. Flash floods can pose hazards when they pour across roadways. While driving, if you should arrive at a low-water crossing during a flood, stop and wait. Ironically, a major cause of death in the desert is drowning!
audioDescription: From this mile marker one has a long distance view towards the west, across the desert flats to mountains located just outside the park boundary. The section of land that was added to the park is mostly flat desert covered in creosote bushes, mesquite, cholla, and yucca. A number of normally dry washes bisect the land, draining water from higher areas across the flats. There are several low-water crossings along this stretch of road that were repeatedly washed out before the construction of higher, stronger bridges.

quickFacts.value: 22 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #24
listingDescription: Dog Canyon cuts through the Santiago Mountains, providing a narrow route of entry into the park from the east. The camel corps of 1859 traveled through this canyon on their expeditions to survey Big Bend country.

images.altText: A dirt trail leads across the flat desert to a rocky wash, which bisects a mountain ridge.
images.title: Dog Canyon Trail
images.caption: The trail to Dog Canyon

bodyText:
A short distance from the rockslide scar, Dog Canyon cuts through the Santiago Mountains. Although the real source of the canyon's name is unknown, it was called "Canon del Perro" by the Spaniards in the late 1700s. When the United States won control of this Big Bend territory, the army was sent to map it. In the late 1850s numerous expeditions surveyed the area. The rugged terrain and climate caused the army to experiment with camels as beasts of burden. Lt. William Echols led his 1859 camel expedition through Dog Canyon. The unique experiment ended when the Civil War erupted. 
Ahead, a roadside exhibit gives more information about the camel experiment and expeditions. During cooler months, consider a half-day hike to Dog Canyon from the exhibit pullout.
audioDescription: By following the line of cliffs to the right of the rockslide, one can view the cut in the Santiago Mountains that is Dog Canyon. A trail from the paved highway leads across flat, sparsely vegetated terrain to a rocky wash. Walking this wash to the east allows one to access the narrow confines of Dog Canyon. Some of the oldest rocks in the park reveal themselves in the walls of the canyon.

quickFacts.value: 24 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #25
listingDescription: In 1987 the late evening silence was shattered by a rumbling rockslide that could be heard for miles. This large scar is evidence of the powerful forces of erosion that are slowly wearing down the Santiago Mountains.

images.altText: A limestone cliff face reveals a white scar with rock boulders underneath from a rockslide.
images.title: Santiago Mountains Rockslide
images.caption: This rockslide occurred more than 30 years ago

bodyText: Evidence of erosion is visible everywhere you turn in Big Bend National Park. A great example of the power of water and gravity on rock is located just up the road. Keep an eye on your left, where a large scar on the Santiago Mountains marks the spot. Late one evening in 1987, a rockslide occurred along this cliff face, creating a tremendous noise that was heard by park staff at Persimmon Gap. Soft Del Rio claystones located directly underneath hard Santa Elena limestone eroded, undercutting the limestone cliff until portions of it collapsed. Even though it appears to have happened yesterday, this scar is a testament to the vast amount of time that it takes for erosion to wear down the mountains of West Texas.
audioDescription: Driving past the Santiago Mountains, a huge white scar near the top of the line of cliffs marks the location of where the rockslide occurred. The limestone itself has been weathered over time to a dull gray color, so the white rock that was exposed after the rock peeled away from the cliff stands out for miles. Piles of large boulders and debris litter the base of the cliff where small shrubs and trees have been growing for the last 30 years. This white scar is visible at Panther Junction, almost 30 miles away!

quickFacts.value: 25 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #26
listingDescription: The low pass at Persimmon Gap was a natural trail for indigenous people, explorers, and pioneers for hundreds of years. As the only natural pass through the Santiago Mountains for many miles, today's travelers follow in the footsteps of history.

images.altText: A low pass in a line of cliffs allows access for a highway.
images.title: Persimmon Gap distant
images.caption: It's easy to see where the road is headed

bodyText: Persimmon Gap began as a stream valley, but later the stream changed course, leaving the Gap dry. This low pass became a natural trail for native people, including the Comanches, who were fierce raiders from the north. During the full moon of September and after the summer rains, they headed south into Mexico. The raiders returned with captives and livestock. The annual north and south passage of people and livestock created a trampled band of earth known as the Great Comanche Trail.
audioDescription: This low pass in the Santiago Mountains is visible from both the north and south for a great distance. As the only natural path through the cliffs, it has been an obvious choice of passage for thousands of years. First on foot, then on horseback, and eventually by car, residents and visitors to Big Bend have all experienced the same "first" view of Big Bend country.

quickFacts.value: 26 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #3
listingDescription: This location provides a view of the Panther Junction community and National Park Service offices.

images.altText: Around 60 buildings dot the landscape below two large peaks in a mountain range.
images.title: Panther Junction community
images.caption: Panther Peak and Wright Peak rise over the community

bodyText: At the base of the Chisos Mountains you can see the community of Panther Junction. This location is not only the park's headquarters, Panther Junction is also the main residential area for employees and their families. As a large national park, Big Bend employs rangers in resource management, law enforcement, interpretation, administration, and maintenance. The Big Bend community also includes concession employees of Forever Resorts, postal workers, school teachers, volunteers, and Border Patrol agents. To serve families living here, the San Vicente School accommodates kids in kindergarten through 8th grades. Attendance averages 20-30 students per year. Once they reach the 9th grade, students attend high school in the community of Terlingua, 45 minutes away.
audioDescription: Looking south one can see the light-colored roofs of at least 50 structures built at the base of two peaks. The visitor center is the larger building in the foreground, while more offices and residences are spread up further up the hill. On the day this picture was taken low, gloomy clouds rested just above the tops of the peaks, lending an aura of gloom to the peaks and ridges.

quickFacts.value: 3 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #5
listingDescription: Just up the road is a pullout on the left that provides access to a short trail. This trail leads to an information panel about Nina and Curtis Hannold, as well as the gravesite of Nina Hannold.

images.altText: A metal fence surrounds a gravesite covered with large rocks with a granite headstone.
images.title: Nina Hannold Gravesite
images.caption: The final resting place of Nina Seawell Hannold

bodyText: About one mile ahead on the left is a pullout that allows access to a short dirt trail. This trail leads to an information sign and the gravesite of Nina Hannold. Curtis and Nina Hannold started a ranch near this location in 1908. Like many early homesteaders in Big Bend country they had to be self-sufficient, resilient, and enterprising. Mr. Hannold supplemented the family income by teaching school at Dugout Wells, seven miles to the south. Stop at this exhibit to learn more about the Hannold family and why Nina chose this location for her final resting place.
audioDescription: Looking south from the gravesite, one has a fantastic view of the Chisos Mountains, rising abruptly from the low desert. The highest point, Emory Peak (7,820 feet) is visible in the middle of the range. The gravesite and wayside are situated on a level bench with the paved road running to the west and a drainage carving the bench to the north. This location affords a 360 degree view, as there are no trees in the immediate area.

quickFacts.value: 5 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #6
listingDescription: This section of road is covered with ocotillo plants, a rare sight for people visiting from the East. The plant has a completely different appearance based on whether or not it received moisture.

images.altText: Two contrasting ocotillo branches. One is white with no leaves and the other is brown with leaves.
images.title: Ocotillo branches
images.caption: The two faces of ocotillo

bodyText: As the road ascends the hill, notice the conspicuous desert plant growing along the hillsides. One of the most common questions answered by park rangers at Big Bend is, "What is the name of that plant with tall, thin, vertical branches that we see everywhere in the park?". This plant is called an ocotillo (pronounced o-ko-tee-yo), and it has developed an unusual mechanism to conserve water in this dry environment. Most of the year this unique plant appears to be nothing more than a cluster of gray thorny stalks that many people mistake for a cactus. With adequate rain, ocotillo will produce numerous bright green leaves that allow for a "spurt" of growth. When the soil dries, the leaves drop off to conserve moisture. Although the plant appears dormant, it can still photosynthesize through the green stripes on its bark.
audioDescription: One of the dominant plants in this section of the road is appears foreign to most people. It averages 6-10 feet (1.8-3.0 meters) in height and is composed of individual vertical stalks to normally do not branch. During dry periods, the stalk appears gray and lifeless, but when it rains the stalk swells up, turns brown and green and sprouts many small leaves all over the stalk.

quickFacts.value: 6 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #8
listingDescription: Right before this mile marker a long bridge crosses a normally dry drainage known as Tornillo Creek. The length and height of the bridge is a testament to the amount of water than can flow under it following thunderstorms.

images.altText: A bridge crosses a wide, dry wash with the Chisos Mountains rising in the distance.
images.title: Tornillo Creek drainage
images.caption: This drainage gathers water from a large area to the west

bodyText: You just passed over Tornillo Creek. Did you see any water? The usually dry creek bed drains the eastern portion of the park. For brief periods after summer thunderstorms, this desert stream roars. The height and width of this bridge is a testament to the amount of water that can flow beneath it! Sixteen miles downstream, Tornillo Creek joins the Rio Grande at Hot Springs. How did this creek get its name? Tornillo is Spanish for "screw," and refers to the shape of the bean produced by the screwbean mesquite. This mesquite can be found in many locations along the creekbed, providing support for the banks of the wash.
audioDescription: A bridge crosses a wide, sandy creek bed, lined with mesquites, willows, creosotebush, and acacia. To the south, one has a great view of the high Chisos Mountains. In front of the mountains are several lines of low colorful clay hills and sandstone rocks known as hoodoos. The few times of the year when water is present, it rapidly flows from west to east, or from the right side of the bridge to the left. When Tornillo Creek is full of water, it sounds like the constant roar of traffic on a freeway.

quickFacts.value: 8 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mile Marker #9
listingDescription: A short distance down the road is the turn-off for the Fossil Discovery Exhibit. This covered exhibit area houses replicas of fossils spanning a 130-million year history of Big Bend.

images.altText: A metal building lies next to a paved trail that climbs a hill to several information exhibits.
images.title: Fossil Discovery Exhibit
images.caption: The Discovery Center, picnic area, and paved trail

bodyText: Swamps covered this area when Big Bend emerged from the sea 70 million years ago. Fossils from the muds and clays of these swamps tell about the last days of the dinosaurs. After the dinosaurs became extinct, mammals rose to dominance. In Big Bend, the swamps gave way to forests. The Fossil Discovery Exhibit, 1/2 mile down the road, allows visitors to experience Big Bend's prehistoric plants and animals, and the world they lived in, through 130 million years of geologic time. Specimens from Big Bend's remarkable fossil record and vivid artwork illustrate the fascinating story of Big Bend's ancient life. A short trail also leads to a panoramic view of nearby geologic points of interest, and highlights the sediments that protect Big Bend's fossils. In addition to the main building and trail, the area around the exhibit includes covered picnic tables, a play area, and a vault toilet.
audioDescription: The Fossil Discovery Exhibit is composed of three separate "activity areas". Nearest to the parking area is a large shade structure that covers two picnic tables. Next to the picnic tables is a kids play area with several structures made to look like dinosaur bones in the process of being excavated. A roughly 20-foot piece of metal has cut-outs that recreate a large dinosaur. The second "activity area" is the main exhibit, which is composed of several outdoor, covered rooms. These rooms are connected with a level floor and each hold glass displays that showcase fossils found in Big Bend National Park. In the central area, there are 3 casts of dinosaurs found in the park. The third "activity area" is a paved path that climbs a hill to an overlook. Spaced out along the paved path are three waysides discussing the geology of the area. Nearing the top of the hill the paved path ends and the trail becomes a series of rock steps that end at the top of the rise. There is one remaining wayside at the top of the hill that discusses the Chisos Mountains, which are visible to the south.

quickFacts.value: 9 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mule Ears Overlook
listingDescription: Mule Ears Peaks is a distinctive igneous formation seen from many places in the park. Stop and enjoy the view across the desert to the Mule Ears.

images.altText: A view across the desert with Mule Ears Peaks in the background.
images.title: View from Mule Ears Overlook
images.caption: A view of Mule Ears Peaks from near the overlook.

bodyText:
A landscape of violence and desert beauty unfolds before you. To the left are two distinctive eroded rhyolite dikes known as Mule Ears Peaks. In the valley floor, deposits of white volcanic tuff erode from the slopes and hard lavas cap the mountains. Mule Ears Overlook is a great place to watch the morning sun greet the desert.

The overlook is a 0.5 mile drive off Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive. Twenty-one pull-in parking places are available and a curb ramp and sidewalk make the overlook wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription: In the foreground, eroded hills expose layers of white volcanic tuff deposits topped by desert scrub vegetation. In the distance is Mule Ears Peak. The peak has two distinctive conical peaks that resemble the ears of a mule. Although they look like the peaks of volcanoes, the Mule Ears formations are actually two eroded rhyolite dikes.

quickFacts.value: 14.8 miles from the northern end of Ross Maxwell Scenic Dr.
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Mule Ears Trail
listingDescription: A 3.8-mile roundtrip hike across rolling desert terrain to a year-round spring and historic rock corral.

images.altText: Thick maidenhair ferns grow above the spring pool at Mule Ears Spring.
images.title: Maidenhair Ferns above Mule Ears Spring.
images.caption: Thick maidenhair ferns grow above the spring pool at Mule Ears Spring.

bodyText:
Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 3.8 miles (6 km)
Elevation Change: 880 feet (243 m) cumulative elevation change
Average Hiking Time: 2 hours

Dogs and other pets are not allowed on any trails in the park.

The Mule Ears Spring trail is a hike through the desert to an historic corral and spring. For much of the journey, the trail crosses rolling desert terrain, descending into dry washes and climbing over low divides. Watch for cottonwood trees in the washes. Tallest of the desert trees, cottonwoods mark the location of a spring or water that is relatively close to the surface. Near the end of the trail, you'll skirt a large, rock corral. Continue past the corral and down the drainage to a small spring. The cool, shaded slope is covered with maidenhair ferns. Cattails line the slow-moving spring flow. Sit on the rocks and listen to the sound of water in the desert. Watch for birds coming into the trees, leopard frogs hopping into the water, and dragonflies patrolling the stream. 

Beyond the spring, the Mule Ears Trail connects to the Smoky Creek Trail. Smoky Creek is an 18.3-mile desert hike that connects to the northern end of the Dodson Trail.

Accessibility

Watch for loose gravel and unsteady footing on this rolling dirt and rock trail. You'll need to navigate a number of short, but steep climbs out of the washes and across the divides.

The paved parking lot at the trailhead provides parking for about 15 vehicles.

Hike Smart

Bring plenty of water!
Carry 1 liter of water per person per hour that you plan to hike. The importance of carrying enough water in this hot, dry climate cannot be overstated!

Eat
Your body needs food for energy and salts and electrolytes to replace what it's losing from perspiration. The dry climate at Big Bend means that sweat often evaporates almost instantly; your body is likely losing lots of moisture and salts without you even realizing it. Eat plenty of salty snacks to keep your body's salt-to-water ratio in balance.

Sun protection
Carry sunscreen and use it liberally. Hats are also strongly recommended. It may seem strange to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in hot weather, but many hikers choose lightweight, breathable clothing which covers their arms and legs to protect themselves from the sun. 

Don't leave people behind
If you're hiking in a group, make sure the person in the back always has someone to help.

Be aware of wildlife
Keep an eye out for snakes, and remember to maintain a safe distance between yourself and all wildlife. Animals in the park are wild and should never be approached, harassed or fed.

Don't stack rocks
Cairns are stacks of rocks which are sometimes used to mark trails in areas where they are hard to follow. Randomly stacked rocks can lure hikers off the correct trail.
audioDescription: The trailhead sign reads: "Mule Ears Spring Trail. The Mule Ears Spring Trail leads across the foothills of the mountains, crossing various ridges before leading to a year-round spring. as the trail skirts around Trap Mountain, look for the large cottonwoods that mark Trap Spring on the northern end of the trail. Near the end of the trail is a rock corral. Dry stone construction like this was a popular way to build in the Big Bend, as it didn't require hauling mortar to remote locations. Nearly a century later, many of these walls are still intact, which is a testament to the skill of the builders. These walls have stood the test of time, but remain fragile. Visitors climbing on rock walls have damaged these structures. Just past the stone corral is Mule Ears Spring. The spring itself is overgrown with shrubs, but maidenhair ferns and cattails also grow there. Also look for riparian wildflowers such as cardinal flower, long-spur columbine, and orchids. Please tread lightly, never stepping or damaging this fragile vegetation." Beyond the trailhead sign, the rock and gravel path ascends a hill through desert scrub vegetation.

quickFacts.value: 15 miles from the northern end of the Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Historic ranching
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Nina Hannold's Gravesite
listingDescription: This exhibit discusses Curtis and Nina Hannold, early pioneers in Big Bend country, and their homestead. The gravesite of Nina Hannold is located a short distance down a dirt trail.

images.altText: A grave site covered in rock and cement, with a granite headstone, is surrounded by a metal fence.
images.title: Nina Hannold's Grave
images.caption: The final resting place of Nina Seawell Hannold

bodyText: Curtis and Nina Hannold started a ranch near this location in 1908. Like many early homesteaders in Big Bend country they had to be self-sufficient, resilient, and enterprising. Mr. Hannold supplemented the family income by teaching school at Dugout Wells, seven miles to the south. Stop at this exhibit to learn more about the Hannold family and why Nina chose this location for her final resting place.
audioDescription: Looking south from this wayside, one has a fantastic view of the Chisos Mountains, rising abruptly from the low desert. The highest point, Emory Peak (7,820 feet) is visible in the middle of the range. The gravesite and wayside are situated on a level bench with the paved road running to the west and a drainage carving the bench to the north. This location affords a 360 degree view, as there are no trees in the immediate area. Text on the wayside: "This grave is one of the few visible traces of Curtis and Nina Hannold's pioneer homestead. In 1908 the Hannolds moved here from Oklahoma by covered wagon. While Nina took care of the ranch and three children, Curtis supplemented their income by teaching school at Dugout Wells eight miles away. At age 29, Nina contracted uremic poisoning during pregnancy, and died September 30, 1911. She asked to be buried on this hill overlooking the spring where she had often read to the children in the shade of the cottonwoods. There are other settler's stories scattered throughout Big Bend, but most of the evidence has been reclaimed by the desert or lost in the vastness."

quickFacts.value: 4 miles north of Panther Junction
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Officer’s & Noncommissioned Officer’s Quarters (Temporary Ranger Station/Visitor Center)
listingDescription: At Castolon, in addition to the barracks, separate houses were built to house the commissioned officers and non-commissioned officers. Over the years these houses have been occupied by the Cartledge family, La Harmonia Company employees, visiting researchers and national park staff. Please respect the privacy of residents using buildings as residence.

images.altText: Officer’s & Noncommissioned Officer’s Quarters (Temporary Ranger Station/Visitor Center)
images.title: Officer’s Quarters
images.caption: Officer’s & Noncommissioned Officer’s Quarters (Temporary Ranger Station/Visitor Center)

bodyText:
To prevent fraternization between officers and enlisted men, separate quarters were standard for U.S. Army soldiers. At Castolon, in addition to the barracks, separate houses were built to house the commissioned officers and non-commissioned officers. These houses were barely used by the cavalry officers before the Mexican Revolution ended and they were assigned elsewhere. Originally, these houses had porches on each end of the building. However, after Wayne Cartledge purchased them in 1925, he modified the building by enclosing one side on each house to create kitchens for the residents.

Over the years these houses have been occupied by the Cartledge family, La Harmonia Company employees, visiting researchers, and national park staff. One of the houses operates as a ranger station and a temporary Visitor Center. The original Visitor Center was destroyed on May 22, 2019 when a fire in Mexico jumped the Rio Grande. Please respect the privacy of residents in these buildings.
audioDescription: Two wooden buildings sit on the edge of Castolon facing the Rio Grande and Mexico. They are located next to other historic buildings of adobe and wood dating from the 1920s, as well as temporary buildings housing a restroom and concession store. The surrounding desert landscape is dotted with plants such as cacti, creosote bushes, and mesquite trees.

title: Old Castolon Exhibit
listingDescription: The land where Old Castolon lies was owned by Cipriano Hernandez, original builder of the Alvino house. The La Harmonia Store opened in early 1919 and soon became an important part of the Castolon community, before moving to it’s later location within the Castolon Historic District up the road.

images.altText: Adobe Buildings and Wayside Exhibit of Old Castolon
images.title: Old Castolon Exhibit
images.caption: Old Castolon in Castolon Historic District

bodyText:
The land where Old Castolon exists was owned by Cipriano Hernandez, original builder of the Alvino House. In 1914, he sold the land to Clyde Buttrill, who hired James Sublett to operate the farm and store previously run by Hernandez. Sublett built the adobe buildings located here before selling the land to two Texas Rangers, Bates and Jones, in 1918. The next year they sold the land to the newly formed La Harmonia Company.

The La Harmonia Store opened in early 1919 and soon became an important part of the Castolon community, due to the integrity and common sense of Wayne Cartledge. Cartledge developed a reputation as a fair businessman who helped his neighbors, regardless of citizenship or language. Fluent in Spanish and English, he settled disputes, translated letters, provided banking services, and acted as a wholesale distributor of American-made merchandise bound for the remote villages of northern Mexico. In many ways, Wayne Cartledge seemed determined to validate La Harmonia’s name by working for peaceful and harmonious relations between the people of western Texas and northern Mexico.
audioDescription: Three adobe buildings lie ahead of the exhibit sign. A small building, a large one with a flat roof, and a second large building with a pointed tin roof stand next to a curve in the road. The surrounding open desert is interspersed with plants such as cacti, creosote bushes, and mesquite trees. Text on the Exhibit Panel La Harmonia Store: During the Mexican Revolution, life on the border was often chaotic. This adobe structure stood as a symbol of harmony in that perilous time. In 1918, Howard Perry, owner of the Chisos Mining Company in Terlingua, and his bookkeeper, Wayne Cartledge, established a new company called La Harmonia. Spanish for “Harmony,” the name reflected Cartledge’s hope for a peaceful relations among the people of southwest Texas and northern Mexico. The first La Harmonia store was housed in these adobe buildings from 1919 until the end of the Mexican Revolution in 1921. It stocked a variety of merchandise, catering to farmers on both sides of the Rio Grande. With the departure of U.S. Army troops, the store was relocated to its present location in the troop barracks of Castolon. Spanish Translation: Tienda La Harmonia: Durante la Revolución Mexicana, la vida en la frontera era caótica. Esta edificio de adobe se representó como un símbolo de harmonía en este tiempo tumulto. En 1918, Howard Perry, dueño de la compañía Chisos Mining en Terlingua, y su socio Wayne Cartledge, establecieron una nueva compañía llamada La Harmonía. Este nombre reflejo la esperanza de Cartledge de premover relaciones pacíficas entre la gente de Texas y México. Estos edificios de adobe sirvieron como la primera tienda La Harmonia desde 1919 hasta el fin de la Revolución en 1921. Ofreció un gran surtido a los agricultores y rancheros de ambos lados del río. Con la salida del cuerpo militar estadounidense, la tienda se mudó a las barracas militares de Castolon.

title: Old Maverick Road - North End
listingDescription: The Old Maverick Road runs generally north-south between Maverick Junction and Santa Elena Canyon. It is a 14-mile improved dirt road that passes along the Terlingua Creek badlands on the west side of the park.This road may quickly become impassable after any rain.

images.altText: View of Santa Elena Canyon along the Old Maverick Road
images.title: Old Maverick Road view
images.caption: View of Santa Elena Canyon along the Old Maverick Road

bodyText:
The Old Maverick Road runs between Maverick Junction and Santa Elena Canyon. It is a 14-mile improved dirt road that passes along the Terlingua Creek badlands on the west side of the park. A number of historic sites are located near the road that you may visit as you gradually descend to the Rio Grande and Santa Elena Canyon.

While usually passable for most vehicles, this road tends to be rough and washboarded; the fourteen miles takes around an hour to drive. This road often becomes impassable following any rain, and may be closed when conditions are dangerous. 

Protect YOUR Big Bend. Always stay on established roadways. 
OFF ROAD DRIVING IS PROHIBITED.

Learn more about Big Bend's Improved Dirt Roads
audioDescription: The Old Maverick Road runs 14 miles south from here to Santa Elena Canyon, one of Big Bend's most picturesque features. The road surface is gravel and usually washboarded. After rains, the route may become impassable. The road passes through the park's remote western badlands, and offers distant expansive views of the Chisos Mountains, and massive limestone cliffs of Santa Elena Canyon.

title: Old Ore Road - North End
listingDescription: Interesting geology and historical sites are among the highlights of this 26-mile rocky, rugged road. The Old Ore Road is rough and requires a sturdy vehicle with good tires to negotiate. The road has excellent views of the Chisos Mountains across the Tornillo Creek drainage to the west. The colorful geology of Ernst Tinaja, five miles from the southern end of the road, is a popular destination.

images.altText: Along the Old Ore Road
images.title: Along the Old Ore Road
images.caption: Along the Old Ore Road

bodyText:
Used in the early 1900s to transport ore from Mexican mines to the railroad station at Marathon, the rugged 26 mile long Old Ore Road generally follows the route used by mule and pack trains a century ago. Drivers can access this road from the southern end near Rio Grande Village, or the northern end along the Dagger Flat Road. It takes approximately 3 to 4 hours to drive the entire road from one end to the other.

The Old Ore Road is very rocky and rough and requires a sturdy vehicle with good tires to negotiate. Be prepared, the northern portion of this road is much rougher and challenging than the southern half. A variety of primitive roadside campsites (permit required) provide opportunities to spend more time in this remote area. The road has excellent views of the Chisos Mountains across the Tornillo Creek drainage to the west. The colorful geology of Ernst Tinaja, five miles from the southern end of the road, is a popular destination.

Before heading out on this road, be well prepared for safe backcountry driving with plenty of water, a jack, and good spare tire. On this isolated, infrequently patrolled backcountry road, a disabled vehicle can quickly become a life-threatening situation.

Protect Big Bend. Always stay on established roadways. 
OFF ROAD DRIVING IS PROHIBITED.
audioDescription: From here, the rugged Old Ore Road winds its way for 26 miles through the remote Dead Horse Mountains. This road follows the route used by mule and pack trains over a century ago and eventually ties into the paved road near Rio Grande Village. The road requires high clearance and 4 wheel drive to safely negotiate. Along the way, drivers enjoy expansive desert views and spectacular geology. It takes approximately four hours to negotiate this entire route. For those who wish to get away from it all, there are 11 popular primitive campsites located along this route (permit required).

title: Ore Tramway Exhibit
listingDescription: The ore tramway that once spanned the Rio Grande near this location facilitated mining operations in Mexico.

images.altText: An exhibit features historic images of the aerial tramway used to transport ore from the mines.
images.title: Aerial tramway exhibit.
images.caption: The aerial tramway exhibit faces the footings of the first tramway tower.

bodyText: Standing at the tramway exhibit you are about midway between the Puerto Rico mine in Mexico and the tramway terminal at the top of the mountain above Ernst Valley. There were actually two tramways. An earlier, smaller, tram was built near the current Port of Entry. Remnants of the larger operation can still be seen along the Ore Terminal trail.  At the terminal, the ore was shipped via wagon to the railroad in Marathon on a road constructed specifically for ore haulage.
audioDescription: Standing at the tramway exhibit you are about midway between the Puerto Rico mine in Mexico and the tramway terminal at the top of the mountain above Ernst Valley. The tramway was used to bring the ore from Mexico, to a wagon road, and then on to the railroad at Marathon. The del Carmen mountains dominate the view to the east, and the rugged Dead Horse mountains are to the north. The mouth of Boquillas Canyon can be seen to the east.

quickFacts.value: 3.5 miles down Boquillas Canyon Road

title: Persimmon Gap
listingDescription: Persimmon Gap marks the northern entrance to the park. It is a great location to stretch your legs after a long drive, use the restroom, and take in the view of where you are headed.

images.altText: A mountain and line of cliffs stand out against a low desert landscape.
images.title: Persimmon Gap
images.caption: Mountains surrounding the Gap

bodyText: Named for the Texas persimmon trees growing here, Persimmon Gap is an ancient place. Almost 300 million years ago, this area was a great mountain range. But even as the mountains rose, erosion wore them down. After millions of years, only gentle hills remained. Then the land slowly subsided until, 150 million years ago, a sea covered this area and buried the hills with sediment. Later, the same uplift that raised the Rocky Mountains raised the present-day Santiago Mountains around you. Their creation thrust up the long-buried rock from the older mountains. In the hills across the road from the visitor center that ancient rock is exposed...the oldest rock in the park!
audioDescription: Standing at Persimmon Gap, one feels like they have traveled through a man-made pass in the mountains. The Santiago range lies on both sides of the road, with the low gap offering the only passage through. Like entering a portal to a hidden valley, the landscape of Big Bend National Park stretches out before you. The Rosillos Mountains rise immediately to the south, offering a clue to the even higher Chisos Mountains that are just out of view.

quickFacts.value: 42 miles south of Marathon, TX on Hwy 385
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Persimmon Gap Entrance
listingDescription: The park sign at Persimmon Gap marks the northern entrance to Big Bend National Park. Named for the Mexican Persimmon trees growing here, this low pass through the Santiago Mountains has been a natural travel corridor for hundreds of years.

images.altText: A stone and concrete sign with Big Bend's title sits adjacent to a paved vehicle pullout.
images.title: Persimmon Gap Entrance Sign
images.caption: Entrance sign at the north side of the park

bodyText: This sign marks the northern entrance to Big Bend National Park. Situated at the base of a low saddle in the surrounding mountains, one has a good view of the country to the north and east. This natural pass through the Santiago Mountains has defined the path of travel into and out of Big Bend country for centuries. Todays' visitors to Big Bend follow a route that was created long ago, not by vehicles, but by the repeated tread of feet and hooves. As you follow these historic footprints into the park, try to imagine traversing this landscape on foot. How would your Big Bend experience be different?
audioDescription: From the pullout looking south, you are facing a rock and concrete sign with the words Big Bend National Park, Rio Grande Wild and Scenic River, a U.S. Biosphere Reserve. On the right side of the sign is a National Park Service arrowhead. Beyond the sign are a line of mountains bisected by a low saddle, known as Persimmon Gap, through which the highway passes. The vegetation on the surrounding hillsides includes cacti, yucca, creosotebush, shrubs, and mesquite trees, to name a few. The gap gets its name from the numerous persimmon trees that grow in the drainages around this low pass.

quickFacts.value: 40 miles south of Marathon, TX on Hwy 385
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Persimmon Gap Entrance Station
listingDescription: This is the entrance station on the north side of the park, 42 miles south of the town of Marathon. Visitors pay an entrance fee which is valid for 7 days, and are given a park map and newspaper.

images.altText: An adobe structure sitting in the middle of the highway has a window where visitors pay to enter.
images.title: Persimmon Gap Entrance Station
images.caption: First view of the Chisos Mountains

bodyText: The Persimmon Gap entrance station is the first location upon entering the park where visitors have the chance to speak with a ranger. Park entrances are always open and you can arrive at any hour, but entrance fee stations may not be staffed. If, during normal business hours, the entrance station is closed, please proceed to the nearest visitor center to pay your entrance fee and collect a park map and newspaper.
audioDescription: An small adobe building sits in the middle of the road, with the two lanes wrapping around the structure. Yucca, an acacia tree, an ocotillo and a prickly pear cactus fill the median in front of the structure. A small window on the west side of the building allows a Park Ranger to speak with visitors and collect entrance fees from those entering the park. A view to the south reveals the rising majesty of the Chisos and Rosillos Mountains.

quickFacts.name: Location

title: Rancher's Oasis Wayside
listingDescription: Under the shade of pecan and walnut trees, learn more about this early 20th-century ranch.

images.altText: An interpretive panel in the shade of large pecan trees.
images.title: Rancher's Oasis Wayside
images.caption: In the shade of pecan trees, an interpretive panel reveals the story of the Nail ranch.

bodyText: Set in the shade of pecan and walnut trees, this interpretive exhibit describes life on an early 20th century ranch.
audioDescription: Set in the shade of pecan and walnut trees, an interpretive exhibit describes life on the Nail's early 20th century ranch. In front of the exhibit is a working windmill that pumps water into a shallow pool. Behind the exhibit is a bench where you can sit and listen to the birds and wildlife that come to the water. The exhibit reads: "Rancher's Oasis. In this green shade it is easier to understand how Sam and Nena Nail could adapt to life in the desert. Here they dug a well, put in a garden, and built holding pens for horses, chickens, and a milk cow. Like other ranchers in the area, the Nails ran stock and dealt with drought, predators, and isolation. The Nail Family has left the Big Bend, but the well they dug still pumps, keeping their trees and shrubs alive. Listen for birdsong, and rustlings in the grass. Life continues to thrive at the oasis."

quickFacts.value: About halfway around the Nail Ranch walking trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Recreation Hall
listingDescription: The recreation hall was built with funds donated by the Salvation Army and was intended to provide leisure time activities for soldiers stationed at the outpost of Camp Santa Helena. The recreation hall still serves as a utility building.

images.altText: Adobe structure and tin roof of the Recreation Hall in Castolon District
images.title: Recreation Hall
images.caption: Recreation Hall in the Castolon Historic District

bodyText: The recreation hall was built with funds donated by the Salvation Army and was intended to provide leisure time activities for soldiers stationed at the outpost of Camp Santa Helena. Life at Camp Santa Helena was isolated and left little opportunity for amusement for young soldiers. Wayne Cartledge later converted the recreation hall into a garage and workshop. It housed the electric generator that brought lights and power to the buildings in the compound. The recreation hall still serves as a utility building.
audioDescription: A large adobe building with a raised tin roof and two garage-sized doors with a regular door in the front stands in the desert. Parking is available for cars and RVs to the side. Other historic buildings of adobe and wood dating from the 1920s are nearby, as well as a temporary building housing a concessions store. The surrounding area is dotted with plants such as cacti, creosote bushes, and mesquite trees.
